column4: Something I've wondered for a while: Is there a way of generating a minimal list of packages to install to get all packages currently installed on a system?
you also can get with dpkg --get-selections
stop using aptitude and use apt-get
The issue is that tasksel uses aptitude, and that tasksel is in the text-mode installer, not that I'm using aptitude myself.
I'm fully familiar with apt-get, I just wish the alternate (and minimal) CDs would use it instead of aptitude (although I can see the use of the latter for the "manual package selection" option.
I discourage you to use that
I /don't/ use the "manual package selection" option.  I /have/ used the tasksel interface, which /still/ calls aptitude.
the best usually is to do it yourself. you can take all the manually selected ones, and filter the not real ones

I know - that's what I'm doing, in conjunction with "aptitude why" (if you can give me an apt-get or apt-cache equivalent, that'd be great, incidentally), I was just hoping for something involving a little less manual effort.
Not the same; aptitude why gives results based on what else is installed, apt-cache (r)depends just gives a dependency list, which is /much/ more effort to work out.
ogra_:  Incidentally, I found something that looks very much like what I was after in deborphan.  Thanks for your suggestions.
Lists installed packages with no installed reverse dependencies, or that's what the extended description suggests.
but, apt detects automatically those ones
No, apt only automatically detects those where they were pulled in as dependencies of something else.  Deborphan, if I read it aright, will pick up ones that weren't.
A quick test (deborphan -a | most) suggests it does what I wanted - it's picking up even things that were manually installed.
The minimal CDs are not packages and cannot be downloaded with apt-get.  Use wget instead.
